posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: Our team used two Limelight cameras this year—one an LL3G configured specifically for April tagging, and the other a standard LL3 model used mainly for pole detection. Both cameras were connected to auxiliary ports on our radio network using CAT6 cables. We chose not to use Power over Ethernet (POE) and didn't require additional Ethernet devices, so we didn't need an extra switch. However, we experienced occasional issues where, roughly 5% of the time, either camera failed to establish Ethernet communication. In such cases, the blinking LEDs on both the radio and camera ports remained unlit. Resetting the camera by cycling its power or simply reinserting the Ethernet cable usually restored communication. Interestingly, the time it took for the connection to resume after reconnecting the cable was about the same as performing a full power cycle on the camera. Have you encountered similar problems? Could there be something specific related to NT4 connections that we're missing?

posts.name: Clayton Colburn
posts.cooked: We encountered a similar issue where approximately 50% of the time, one of our two lime lights wouldn’t connect during field use. We attempted multiple troubleshooting steps, including testing both P OE and non-P OE configurations, as well as setting up both automatic and static IP addresses, but none of these methods resolved the problem. The only effective solution was implementing a network switch. Based on this experience, we concluded that the Aux ports on the new radios are not consistently reliable for connecting lime lights.

We struggled with this issue throughout the year. At Curie, the head of the FIRST Technical Advisor (FTA) informed us that the problem was due to slow boot times from Limelights, which affected the Robo RIO's ability to provide IP addresses within a limited timeframe. However, we have not personally verified this claim. This issue sometimes presented itself as a dead port on the vh-109, where no lights would blink on the affected "dead" port. After performing a reboot, the issue was usually resolved.

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: The added network switch still would have had to be connected to one of the aux ports on the radio, right? To be able to talk to the RIO, which has to be plugged into the RIO port of the radio.

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: Thanks. I thought it was required that RoboRIO had to be plugged directly into the radio, but I must be mistaken. We also battled what seemed to be slow vision pose updates occasionally (only during autonomous running path planner paths and only when connected to the field). I wonder if adding the switch would have helped us out with that. But all I can do is wonder now... until next season. Thanks for the input.

posts.name: Casey Stahl - 2358 - Robot Repairman (Mentor)
posts.cooked:
We also encountered similar issues frequently, though less consistently than at WI. Additionally, poor lighting conditions during another instance added to our challenges. In some cases, we had to perform power cycles on the robot multiple times. On one occasion, it required three power cycles during a match. To ensure the robot was ready as quickly as possible, we began powering it up 20 seconds before the previous match ended. This allowed us extra time to reset it if needed. I also made a habit of checking the cable connections every time, but this didn’t seem to resolve the recurring issues.

Ultimately, we brought a test tag to verify if the camera could detect it. Our technician would either give us a thumbs-up or -down signal, and if necessary, perform a power cycle. This entire process was quite frustrating, and I believe we never repeated this setup in the pit again. Last year’s problems with an Ethernet switch prevented us from installing one during that period.

posts.cooked: "Was this issue only present on FMS?"

posts.name: Dylan Li
posts.cooked:
Is your RIO configured to have a Static IP?

We had an issue last year with our LimeLight not connecting to our RIO during competitions. It wasn't resolved and we switched to Photon Vision this season, but we noticed that Photon Vision's documentation recommends a static IP for the RIO, which we didn't set up for LimeLight last year.
We had this issue as well with static IPs configured on both of our Limelights. A reboot consistently fixed the issue.

I guess I thought when configuring the team number on RIO that it became a static IP... at 10.xx.xx.2, the IP address. Is there another step needed to ensure it is static? Both our limelights are definitely set to static IPs."

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: Clayton_Colburn said: "You would connect Roborio to the switch and then connect the switch to the Rio port on the radio." This configuration is illegal per R703.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: When this issue occurred, were you able to view the camera feed when accessing the Limelight directly via a web browser?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Clayton Colburn
posts.cooked: A specific Ethernet port should be used for the roboRIO. This port must be connected to the wireless bridge port labeled “RIO” for VH-109 radios or “18-24v P OE” for OpenMesh radios. The connection can be direct, through a network switch, or via an RPM (Revolutions Per Minute) or a CAT5 Ethernet pigtail. The rule explicitly allows for direct or network switch connections, as indicated in the parentheses.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: When using an "18-24v P.O.E." for OpenMesh radios, the power can be supplied directly, through a network switch, via an RPM (Revolutions Per Minute), or via a CAT5 Ethernet pigtail. This setup is typically utilized when employing the OMP5 platform, which remains in use in regions such as China and Taiwan. Images associated with this discussion are provided for reference but do not alter the technical specifications or context of the information shared.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.cooked: There is no connectivity. No data is populated in NT, and no web stream is available.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: When attempting to access the Limelight's web configuration interface via its static IP, you may encounter issues such as the interface opening without a camera stream or encountering problems. To troubleshoot, check if the interface loads properly and verify network connectivity by pinging the Limelight.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.cooked: We couldn't successfully ping the static IP or hostname. The web interface was completely inaccessible, as though the Limelight wasn't connected to the robot.

posts.name: Jared Russell
posts.cooked:
We also experienced occasional connection issues with Limelight 4 when the robot booted up. Restarting the robot seemed to resolve the problem each time.  

We utilized static IPs, applied the most recent firmware updates, and encountered issues with the gateway initially set to x.1 (as per the official Limelight documentation), before being informed that the correct gateway should actually be x.4.
